narrative: From a text-based MUD created in a kitchen to one of the world's longest-running MMORPGs, RuneScape has defined a generation of online gaming. This story traces the evolution of Gielinor, exploring the technological leaps from Classic to RS3, the controversial updates that fractured the player base, and the unprecedented success of Old School RuneScape driven by community democracy.

slides.title: The Kitchen Table Origins (1998-2001)
slides.content: The story begins with Andrew and Paul Gower developing 'DeviousMUD' and early versions of RuneScape from their parents' home in Nottingham. Written in Java, this browser-based game allowed for accessibility that competitors couldn't match, laying the groundwork for a massive online community.
slides.imagePrompt: A nostalgic late 90s setting featuring a bulky beige CRT monitor displaying raw Java code and a primitive pixelated game map. On the desk, sketches of medieval fantasy weapons and a cup of tea, creating an atmosphere of indie game development.

slides.title: RuneScape Classic Launches (2001)
slides.content: officially released in 2001, 'RuneScape Classic' introduced players to a persistent world of skills, quests, and open PvP. Despite its simple 2D sprites and reliance on a 'sleeping bag' mechanic to reduce fatigue, it rapidly gained millions of registered accounts due to its free-to-play model.
slides.imagePrompt: A screenshot-style illustration of RuneScape Classic featuring 2D sprite characters in plate armor, simple low-resolution textures, and a distinct UI with a chat box at the bottom. The scene depicts players fishing and lighting fires near a castle.

slides.title: The Golden Age: RuneScape 2 (2004)
slides.content: A massive engine overhaul transitioned the game into full 3D, bringing vastly improved graphics, sound, and the removal of the fatigue system. This era is widely considered the 'Golden Age,' introducing iconic content like the Slayer skill and the Barrows minigame.
slides.imagePrompt: A vibrant, high-quality 3D render of the Lumbridge Castle entrance in the style of 2004 graphics. New players with wooden shields are crossing the bridge, while high-level players in Dragon armor stand nearby, showcasing the visual leap from 2D to 3D.

slides.title: The Wilderness & Trade Controversies (2007)
slides.content: In an effort to combat real-world trading and botting, Jagex removed free trade and the Wilderness PvP, causing a massive player revolt. While effective against cheaters, these updates fundamentally changed the game's economy and social structure, leading to riots in Falador.
slides.imagePrompt: A dramatic scene in the virtual city of Falador, depicting a mass gathering of player characters wearing white knight armor protesting. In the background, a dark barrier symbolizes the restricted Wilderness, contrasting with the chaos in the city square.

slides.title: The Evolution of Combat (2012)
slides.content: The 'Evolution of Combat' (EoC) update modernized the game's fighting mechanics, adding action bars and abilities to replace the passive click-and-wait system. This was the most divisive update in history, alienating purists while paving the way for complex boss raids in modern RuneScape.
slides.imagePrompt: A split-screen comparison. On the left, a character performs a simple sword swing. On the right, a dynamic character utilizes a glowing magical ability from an action bar, with particle effects and damage numbers, representing the shift to modern MMO combat.
slides.videoPrompt: An infographic animation showing a static combat stance transforming into a dynamic stance. An action bar slides up from the bottom, and ability icons light up in sequence, demonstrating the shift from passive combat to active ability usage.

slides.title: The Old School Renaissance (2013)
slides.content: Responding to declining player numbers, Jagex opened a poll to restore a 2007 backup of the game. The community voted overwhelmingly 'Yes,' leading to the launch of Old School RuneScape (OSRS), a separate server dedicated to the game's nostalgic legacy mechanics.
slides.imagePrompt: A retro-styled voting booth UI overlaid on a nostalgic login screen with flames. A 'Yes' vote bar is filled to 90% green, symbolizing the community's power. In the background, the tutorial island guide waves welcomingly.

slides.title: A Tale of Two Games (Present Day)
slides.content: Today, RuneScape exists as two distinct entities: the modern, graphically impressive RS3 and the community-driven, retro-styled OSRS. Both versions thrive on mobile and PC, proving that gameplay depth and community matter more than cutting-edge graphics.
slides.imagePrompt: A conceptual image showing a mirror reflection. On one side is a high-fidelity, modern RuneScape character fighting a massive boss. On the other side is the retro, polygon-heavy Old School character fishing peacefully, illustrating the coexistence of both versions.
